body:
Problem:
It's relatively easy to mispress key `a` to (a)llow arbitrary execution
of exrc files. See also discuss https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions/35050.

Solution:
- For exrc files, remove "allow" from choices of `vim.secure.read`.
- Provide better preamble so the user can first (v)iew the file and then
  execute the command `:trust`, which removes the possibility of
  mispress.

comment_data.body: Thank you. My original code is indeed a bad workaround for a pattern matching issue related to line-wrapping. I ended up increasing the screen width to avoid the sequence [`|`,`\n`,`|`] being inserted into any/both of the critical parts of the two filepaths we're interested in here, i.e. `".*/.exrc"`, `".*/.nvim.lua"`. As I realized that `.*` is capturing a runtime path which can be of any length.

comment_regular_data.body:
**Edit**: both are resolved by zeertzjq, ty!

I have some questions:

1. Is it fine to ignore `test / lint` sometimes?
2. Do we have some beginner-friendly `screen:expect` usages for reference? At least I'm still interested in the meaning of `3:` in say `{3:foobar}`, and that of `{MATCH: +}`, since I struggled to update some `*_spec.lua` files by try-and-error.

>     1. Is it fine to ignore `test / lint` sometimes?

No.
 
>     2. Do we have some beginner-friendly `screen:expect` usages for reference? At least I'm still interested in the meaning of `3:` in say `{3:foobar}`, and that of `{MATCH: +}`, since I struggled to update some `*_spec.lua` files by try-and-error.

Did you read the documentation in test/functional/ui/screen.lua?

I think the general idea here is very good but it kinda makes it annoying as well. I don't mind having to open the file and trusting it but then I have to restart neovim to actually have it sourced. It would be nice to source the file immediately after trusting it if it were not already trusted.

I agree that's annoying, but solving it is not trivial. We don't want to source *every* file on `:trust` because the trust system is not just for exrc files, it can be used for anything.

For now at least, the new `:restart` command will be useful to help with this.

> I agree that's annoying, but solving it is not trivial. We don't want to source _every_ file on `:trust` because the trust system is not just for exrc files, it can be used for anything.
> 
> For now at least, the new `:restart` command will be useful to help with this.

Forgive me if I understood the command incorrectly. But the trust command is supposed to trust the current opened file, right? It should source only it when I call `:trust`, not everything.

> But the trust command is supposed to trust the current opened file, right? It should source only it when I call :trust, not everything.

Yes. But `'exrc'` is only one use case for the trust framework. exrc sources trusted files, but we provide a `vim.secure.read()` and `vim.secure.trust()` API that plugins can use to manage trusted files to do with whatever they want. Just because a file is trusted doesn't necessarily mean that it should be sourced.

Also consider a use case where you are viewing an exrc file in a different directory. You can `:trust` that file if you want to, but it shouldn't be sourced in that case since it's not in your current directory.
We should probably change the message to suggest `(v)iew the file then run :trust|source`, or something like that.
